column2: Then he took a deep breath, clenched his hands tightly, and lifted his head.
column3: Then he took a deep breath, clenched his hands tightly, and lifted his head.

column2: There it was!--as Dad had described it, but infinitely more grand.
column3: There it was!--as Dad had described it, but infinitely more grand.

column2: It swept upward from the valley floor, beautifully shaped and soaring, so tall that its misty blue peak could surely talk face to face with the stars.
column3: It swept upward from the valley floor, beautifully shaped and soaring, so tall that its misty blue peak could surely talk face to face with the stars.

column2: To David, who had never seen a mountain before, the sight was almost too much to bear.
column3: To David, who had never seen a mountain before, the sight was almost too much to bear.

column2: He felt so tight and shivery inside that he didn't know whether he wanted to laugh, or cry, or both.
column3: He felt so tight and shivery inside that he didn't know whether he wanted to laugh, or cry, or both.

column2: And the really wonderful thing about the mountain was the way it _looked_ at him.
column3: And the really wonderful thing about the mountain was the way it underscore looked underscore at him.

column2: He was certain that it was smiling at him, like an old friend who had been waiting for years to see him again.
column3: He was certain that it was smiling at him, like an old friend who had been waiting for years to see him again.

column2: And when he closed his eyes, he seemed to hear a voice which whispered, "Come along, then, and climb."
column3: And when he closed his eyes, he seemed to hear a voice which whispered, "Come along, then, and climb."

column2: It would be so easy to go!
column3: It would be so easy to go!

column2: The back yard was hedged in (with part of the hedge growing right across the toes of the mountain), but there was a hole in the privet large enough to crawl through.
column3: The back yard was hedged in (with part of the hedge growing right across the toes of the mountain), but there was a hole in the privet large enough to crawl through.

column2: And just beyond the hedge the mountainside awaited him, going up and up in one smooth sweep until the green and tawny faded into hazy heights of rock.
column3: And just beyond the hedge the mountainside awaited him, going up and up in one smooth sweep until the green and tawny faded into hazy heights of rock.

column2: It was waiting for him.
column3: It was waiting for him.

column2: Come and climb, it whispered, "come and climb."
column3: Come and climb, it whispered, "come and climb."

column2: But there was a great deal to do first.
column3: But there was a great deal to do first.

column2: They were going to move into the new house.

column3: The moving van was standing out in front, the car must be unloaded.

column2: David would be needed to carry things.

column2: Regretfully, he waved his hand at the peak and whispered, "It shouldn't take long--I'll be back as soon as I can." Then he went around to the front door to see what could be done about speeding things up.

column2: Inside, everything was in confusion.

column2: Dad was pushing chairs and tables around in an aimless way.
column3: Dad was pushing chairs and tables around in an aimless way.

column3: When the ironing board was finally located, Mother had something for him to do.

column2: So the afternoon wore on without letup--and also without any signs of progress in their moving.
column3: So the afternoon wore on without letup-and also without any signs of progress in their moving.

column2: When David finally got a chance to sneak out for a breathing spell, he felt his heart sink.
column3: When David finally got a chance to sneak out for a breathing spell, he felt his heart sink.

column2: Somehow, in all the rush and confusion, the afternoon had disappeared.
column3: Somehow, in all the rush and confusion, the afternoon had disappeared.

column2: Already the evening sun was throwing shadows across the side of the mountain and touching its peak with a ruddy blaze.
column3: Already the evening sun was throwing shadows across the side of the mountain and touching its peak with a ruddy blaze.

column2: It was too late now.
column3: It was too late now.

column2: He would have to wait until morning before he could climb.

column2: As he gazed up miserably at the glowing summit, he thought he saw a tiny speck soar out from it in a brief circle.
column3: As he gazed up miserably at the glowing summit, he thought he saw a tiny speck soar out from it in a brief circle.

column2: Was it a bird of some sort, or just one of those dots that swim before your eyes when you stare too long at the sky?

column2: It almost seemed like the mountain waving its hand, as if to say that it was quite all right for him to wait until morning.
column3: It almost seemed like the mountain waving its hand, as if to say that it was quite all right for him to wait until morning.

column2: He felt better then, and returned more cheerfully to the moving.
column3: He felt better then, and returned more cheerfully to the moving.

column2: It was long after dark before the moving van drove away.
column3: It was long after dark before the moving van drove away.

column2: Beckie crooned happily over her bottle, and the rest of them gathered in the kitchen for a late supper of sandwiches and canned soup.
column3: Beckie crooned happily over her bottle, and the rest of them gathered in the kitchen for a late supper of sandwiches and canned soup.

column2: But David could not eat until he had found the courage to ask one question:
column3: But David could not eat until he had found the courage to ask one question:

column2: May I climb the mountain tomorrow?
column3: May I climb the mountain tomorrow?

column2: Aunt Amy muttered something about landslides, which were firmly fixed in her mind as the fate of people who climbed mountains.
column3: Aunt Amy muttered something about landslides, which were firmly fixed in her mind as the fate of people who climbed mountains.

column3: But Dad said, "I don't see why not, do you?" and looked to Mother for agreement.

column3: Mother said, "Well ... be very careful," in a doubtful tone, and that was that.

column2: You never know what you will find when you climb a mountain, even if you have climbed them before--which, of course, David never had. Looking up from the foot of the mountain, he had thought that it was a smooth slope from bottom to top.
column3: You never know what you will find when you climb a mountain, even if you have climbed them before-which, of course, David never had. Looking up from the foot of the mountain, he had thought that it was a smooth slope from bottom to top.

column2: But he was discovering as he climbed that it was not smooth at all, but very much broken up.
column3: But he was discovering as he climbed that it was not smooth at all, but very much broken up.

column2: There were terraces, ledges, knolls, ravines, and embankments, one after another.
column3: There were terraces, ledges, knolls, ravines, and embankments, one after another.

column2: The exciting part of it was that each feature concealed the ones above it.
column3: The exciting part of it was that each feature concealed the ones above it.

column2: At the top of a rise would be an outcropping of strangely colored rock, invisible from below.
column3: At the top of a rise would be an outcropping of strangely colored rock, invisible from below.

column2: Beyond the outcropping, a small stand of aspens would quiver in the breeze, their quicksilver leaves hiding a tiny meadow on the slope behind.
column3: Beyond the outcropping, a small stand of aspens would quiver in the breeze, their quicksilver leaves hiding a tiny meadow on the slope behind.

column2: And when the meadow had been discovered, there would be a something else beyond.
column3: And when the meadow had been discovered, there would be a something else beyond.

column2: He was a real explorer now.
column3: He was a real explorer now.

column2: When he got to the top, he thought, he would build a little tower of stones, the way explorers always do.
column3: When he got to the top, he thought, he would build a little tower of stones, the way explorers always do.

column2: But at the end of two hours' steady climbing, he was ready to admit that he would never reach the peak that day.

column2: It still rose above his head, seeming as far distant as ever.
column3: It still rose above his head, seeming as far distant as ever.

column2: It had been a glorious climb, and the distance he had already covered was a considerable one.
column3: It had been a glorious climb, and the distance he had already covered was a considerable one.

column2: The mountains on the other side of the valley seemed like blue clouds stretching out over the edge of the world.

column2: Even the peak could not give him a better view than this.

column3: David gazed up the face of a scarp which rose like a cliff above him-a smooth, bare wall of rock that had halted his climb.

column2: Halfway up the scarp was a dark horizontal line of bushes, something like a hedge.
column3: Halfway up the scarp was a dark horizontal line of bushes, something like a hedge.

column2: Apparently there was a ledge or shelf there, and he decided to climb up to it before he returned home.
column3: Apparently there was a ledge or shelf there, and he decided to climb up to it before he returned home.

column2: To scale the rock face itself was impossible, however: there were no hand or foot holds.
column3: To scale the rock face itself was impossible, however: there were no hand or foot holds.

column2: So he turned and made his way through the grass until he reached the end of the bare stone.
column3: So he turned and made his way through the grass until he reached the end of the bare stone.

column2: Then he started upward again.
column3: Then he started upward again.

column2: It was hard work.

column2: Vines clutched at his feet, and the close-set bushes seemed unwilling to let him pass.
column3: Vines clutched at his feet, and the close set bushes seemed unwilling to let him pass.

column2: He had one nasty slip, which might have been his last if he had not grabbed a tough clump of weeds at the crucial instant.
column3: He had one nasty slip, which might have been his last if he had not grabbed a tough clump of weeds at the crucial instant.

column2: But, oh! it was worth it.
column3: But, oh! it was worth it.

column2: He felt like shouting when at last he reached the ledge.
column3: He felt like shouting when at last he reached the ledge.

column2: Truly it was an enchanted place!
column3: Truly it was an enchanted place!

column2: It was a long, level strip of ground, several yards wide, carpeted with short grass and dandelions.
column3: It was a long, level strip of ground, several yards wide, carpeted with short grass and dandelions.

column3: He rolled over on his back and cushioned his head in his hands.

column3: The sky seemed to be slipping along overhead like a broad blue river.

column3: Then it would fade and be drowned out by the breeze.

column3: He dropped down on his stomach and carefully began to worm his way under the thicket.

column3: The branches grew very low, and the ground was full of lumps and knobs which dug into him with every movement.
